intro: Angelica chaerophyllea, commonly known as the white angelica, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots, parsley, and celery, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage and showy flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 1 to 2 meters, featuring compound leaves with a feathery appearance and small white to pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels. Its roots are often used in traditional herbal medicine for their purported digestive and anti-inflammatory properties. Angelica chaerophyllea thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland or alpine habitats.
